course.subject: SOSC
course.name: International Law
course.description: International law (IL) is a system of principles than govern relations among states and the human rights of individuals. It is mainly studied through analyzing international agreements (treaties), customs and court decisions. The topics taught in this course are the same as those taught in almost all introductory IL courses everywhere in the world, including the history and sources of IL, states and international organizations; human rights; sea, air and space law; environmental law; the use of force; and the peaceful settlement of disputes. Many of the topics are frequently discussed in the mass media and concern events of world-wide importance.

reviews.author: Law~
reviews.title: Generous Grading but beware of falling into C and D Range
reviews.comment_content:
SOSC1270 introduces the fundamentals of International Law. I personally would interpret it as a 'history' course rather than a law course as a great portion of the course simply outlines the historical development of International law in different areas (such as Human Rights, Territory, Pollution, Nuclear Safety, Armed Conflicts ......), which means there are not many (or very few) legal principles to be remembered.

There are some suggested readings provided in the course but they are not necessary. You can do simply rely on the Lecture Notes because most of the questions were extracted from there (but some questions will be modified to assess the clarity of your concepts)
reviews.comment_teaching:
WARNING: HE IS A PRO-CHINA PROFESSOR

Professor Barry Sautman is one of the very good professors I have met in HKUST. He is a cheerful old person with charisma. In exam 1, he welcomes some of the students to join the course (because many students haven't shown up in any classes before and their participation of Exam 1 is their first time to step into the class)

Although he speaks quite boring and most of the students don't attend his classes, I would say he is a wise person and you would know more about how states deal with each other, and some mechanisms on how global community is solving problems internationally. (yeah it is a good 1000-level course)
reviews.comment_grading:
Very Generous Grading.

In 2017 Spring Semester, he offers 26.9% A-Range (Most of them are concentrated at A). If you get 0.8 SD higher than mean in overall assessment, you will receive A-, if you are 1 SD higher than mean, then you will get a A. Even though you are not very strong and you get 0.5 SD higher than mean, you will secure a B+. This is a very good grade for a course with such low level of workload.

I get a B+ because I screwed my first exam. Each MCQ you attempt = 1% of the course total feedback. Therefore, it means that it is also very easy to get killed in this course.

2017 Spring Semester shows that 4.6% of enrolled students (total of 12) receive an F (which is quite high), he also offers 27 D, and over 80 C-Range (around 125 students receive C+ or below in a 260-student class). Scoring 3/4 marks below mean will get you a C.

For Business School Students, you may treat it as the common core version of ECON2113 (Zhang's section) in terms of grading. If you score above mean, you will have a fun time, but you will definitely suffer with a bad bad bad grade if u score below the mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
0 workload.

No Attendance with all lecture videos released after every class is finished. (but in fact I have never checked out the videos and I start revising the exams 2/3 days before)

In general, I would say hard working students are definitely gaining advantages because the part of "understanding" is important to study IL. So if you are aiming high and self-motivated this is a very good course.

I actually had a tight schedule because I enrolled to 19 credits this semester. I procrastinated until the end. It only took 3~4 full days to prep for the final exam. A tip for a good student, please attend (or at least follow) the class. As I reached to the end, I saw a lot of missing seats since this is a final 100% course. Some of the contents IN the PPT are NOT covered in class while some contents NOT in the PPT ARE covered. Some funny IL examples that Dr. Sautman shares may be on the exam. Its fun when you hear it, so the people in class will not forget them. However, others who just studied through notes won't be able to get some Qs right.

reviews.title: Low-workload SA course, easy to get B range grade with minimal effort
reviews.comment_content:
There are 8 topics, namely
Historical Development of IL;
Treaties, Customs, and Other Sources;
States and Other Entitles;
International Human Rights;
Law of sea, Air and Outer Space;
Environmental Law;
The Use of Force, and;
The Peaceful Settlements of International Disputes;

There are many facts and definitions taught, with the addition of relevant case studies.
reviews.comment_teaching: Barry speaks loudly and clearly, and is very friendly. During class, he will generally just read from the PowerPoint, however he invites discussion if you ask a question.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is a final and no midterm
The final consists of 80 mc questions in 80 minutes, asking about definitions and certain details of case studies.

To achieve a good grade in the final, you need to memorize a lot, but passing is not difficult with common sense. I barely studied (30 minutes of reading the PowerPoint before the final) and got 46/80, which was a B- grade.

There is also an optional essay research paper, where you can work yourself or with a partner. The paper should be 12-15 pages with a topic related to international law. After writing, the group must present their paper to the class in a 15-20 minute presentation. Only 20 groups can write the paper, and who gets to do the paper is done via lucky draw. Both partners share grade equally. I was able to do the paper, and received an A- grade on the paper.

There are 2 grading methods:
Final 100%, or;
Final 50% and Essay 50%

With my combined final grade of B-, and essay grade of A-, I achieved an overall grade of B+. With slightly more than minimal effort, a good grade can be achieved in this course
reviews.comment_workload:
If you are not selected for the essay, there is 0 required workload. There are no assignments, and you don't need to study much unless you want to get A range grade.

There is no attendance for lectures, and all lectures are recorded in case you want to re-watch something.

If you are selected for the essay, expect to spend at least 1 week researching and writing the paper.

reviews.author: a s
reviews.title: Interesting Course
reviews.comment_content:
The contents of this course would interest those who enjoy learning about current affairs, history, etc. It wasn’t very technical but I did learn a lot since the course covers a wide range of topics in a short span of time.

The syllabus is as follows:
Historical Development of IL
Customs and Treaties
States and International Organizations
International Human Rights
Sea, Air, Space Law
Environmental Law
The Use of Force
Peaceful Settlement of Disputes

Aside from lectures, the exam also covers the 12 presentations based on student papers. The results of the lucky draw which determines who gets to write these are announced after the add-drop period, therefore be mentally prepared that you may not get to do a paper. Students could choose to do the papers in pairs so more students are allowed to write. We are also provided with a few articles as supplementary materials for the course but I don’t think it’s necessary to read (I didn't).
This year, the number of presentation-based questions were reduced -- 74 questions were based on lectures and 6 were about student presentations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although I feel he speaks too slowly and somewhat monotonously, Barry is eloquent and his lectures were easy to comprehend. It’s important to watch his lectures, even if you watch at a faster speed, since the lecture notes do not contain all the material covered in the exam.
Since this semester was over zoom, there were some technical difficulties but Barry made sure to answer all our questions -- after lectures, over email or on Canvas. He also holds optional Q&A sessions where we can ask additional questions. Not only is he approachable, but also knowledgeable. His political opinion is quite clear but he doesn’t force it on you.
reviews.comment_grading:
This fall there was only one exam instead of the usual midterm and final, so there were two options:
1) 100% based on final
2) 50% based on final, 50% based on paper
I feel that his grading is quite fair, around a fifth of the class achieved A range this semester. Alas! This is still a UST course, so if you score below mean, you’re bound to get C or below.

As Barry said, most students who do a paper increase their grade by a letter. Based on the sample papers provided to paper writers, it seems if your paper is decently comprehensible and cogent, the paper will raise your grade -- the paper I wrote did increase my grade overall and I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Minimum workload. No attendance. If you choose not to do the paper, all you need to do is understand and recollect the legal principles in the lectures since the exam isn’t based on remembering dates and details of the examples. If you choose to do the paper, it’s a 14 page, double-spaced document and paper-writers are provided with writing workshops and a database with law reviews.

reviews.author: couch_potato
reviews.title: Very good course that helps with basic law and international relations concepts
reviews.comment_content:
The course, in chronological order, talks about:

1. History of development of international law
2. Treaties
3. States
4. Human Rights (largely about legal systems in UN)
5. Environmental Law
6. Law of the Sea, Air and Space
7. Use of Force
8. Peaceful Settlements of International Conflicts

There are a lot of pages in the lecture notes, but if you are able to understand the rationale behind the policies, it isn't too much to bear. I would keep an eye out for Human Rights and Environmental Law though, since I am unable to sort out any logical rationale behind most of the legal systems, so I had to resort to reciting 2 entire 70-page long lecture PPTs. These 2 sections are the reason why I refuse to give this part an A.

In general, the content allows students to learn about standard international law concepts, and along with analysis of some infamous international law cases, it is, in my opinion, quite an enjoyable introductory course in law.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is a very good presenter, with very native English pronunciation, which makes it very easy and comfortable to listen to. The professor explains the concepts and the cases quite clearly, and provides a tutorial Q&A session the day before the 2 exams, which allows students the chance to clarify their confusions before they walk into the exam venue LT-J.

The professor is very supportive and quite willing to answer questions during and after lecture. Yes, I said during. The professor actually really likes it when students ask pertinent questions during class, and will actively ask if there are any questions or comments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Don't be fooled by the promise of 100 MCs, coz as a matter of fact the questions are very difficult. Not only do you have to remember minute details, but your logical ability will be tested as well. The professor has explicitly mentioned that nobody has ever gotten a full mark in any of the exams.

However, the grading isn't that harsh.
For standard students, the entire course consists of 100 MCQ, and each question counts for 1% of the course grade. For people who get to do presentations, their paper will count for 50% of their grades, while each MCQ counts for 0.5% of the course grade.

Statistics will be provided later.

Mid-term: 33/48
Final: 41/52
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
There is basically no workload, unless you count studying for mid-terms and finals as course workload.
For a selected group of volunteers, they get to do a paper that counts for 50% of their grades, as well as a presentation, with their content covering 13 questions in the final exam. It is possible that these volunteers are poor presenters, and/or they may choose to keep their presentation PPT to themselves, a selfish act which a majority of the volunteer groups utilized. It is therefore advised that you register this course with the people you know, as this increases the chance of obtaining the presentation PPT to study. The presentation groups with good heart will upload their PPT onto Canvas.

Attendance is not compulsory, and lecture videos are available on Canvas.

In general, the workload isn't heavy, and most of the stuff can be crammed within 3-4 nights.

reviews.author: Mattpyf
reviews.comment_content: This course will teach you some basic knowledge of international law, including definition, enactment and some of it. Yet, you won't learn much based on the materials provided in the lesson. If you really want to know more about this IL, you need to read the reading materials on your own and it is completely useless for the quiz and examination.
reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly, I think the teaching is quite boring and it does not only because of the professor. As people do not need to take attendance in this course, you will soon find that there are not many people left in the lecture. Also, all the questions asked in the examination can be found in the notes provided so you can totally study it on your own and still have a good grading. That makes the whole atmosphere a little bit boring.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is really good especially to those who are not good at English as all notes and quiz provided both English and Chinese versions. 35% of the grade is the quiz and 65% is the examination. All the questions are mc questions. There are 35questions in the quiz and 65 questions in the examination. It is not difficult to have a good grade if you read the lecture notes carefully.
reviews.comment_workload: As mentioned, you only need to do 100 MC questions throughout this course and you do not need to attend the class so the workload is extremely low.

reviews.author: anniehahalala
reviews.title: Very Good
reviews.comment_content:
Very interesting

Topics for midterm:
-History
-Customs and Treaties
-States and International Organizations
-Human Rights

Topics for final:
-Sea, air, space law
-Environmental law
-Use of force
-Peaceful settlement of disputes
-Student presentations
reviews.comment_teaching: Barry is a passionate prof. who always encourage us to ask questions. There are also tutorials offered after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty good.
Poor Students-about 15% of class
Ave./Good Students-about 60% of clas
Very Good Students-about 15% of class
Excellent Students-about 10% of class

You can volunteer to write and present in class a research paper on a current IL topic.  If you do, the paper will be 50% of your final grade; your exam marks will be the other 50%.  The average grade on papers is generally one full grade higher than the average.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload if you do not do the extra paper. Very Good!

reviews.author: Turtle
reviews.title: Introduction to International Law
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
Historical Development of IL and Customs and Treaties
States and International Organizations
International Human Rights
Sea, Air, Space Law
Environmental Law
The Use of Force and Peaceful Settlement of Disputes

In fact, this course is just a 1xxx level course, which means it is quite easy. The course only focuses on the basic concepts, which means that you do not need to memorise a lot of things. Attending the class, you will be safe.
reviews.comment_teaching: One of the best professors in ust who is willing to answer students' questions in class or after the lesson. He is really familiar with this topic and used a lot of examples in class. He can clearly deliver the ideas to you so that it is not quite hard to pick up all the things. Also the TA is really good. There will be some supplementary tutorial held by the TA to help students fully understand the topics and the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grades:
Excellent Students = ~10%
Very Good Students = ~15%
Ave./Good Students = ~60%
Poor Students = ~15%

If you take this course in the summer semester, actually the grading is much better. I think it is not that difficult to get an A range in this course as quite a lot of my classmates did so.
reviews.comment_workload:
Grade Calculation:
Final Exam = 50%
Project = 50%

Final Exam = 100 MCQs
Project = In-class Presentation + Essay
(Work shared by 2 students)

The questions are quite straightforward. But it is quite intensive as it only take three weeks to finish the course (half of the summer semester). For the project, each group needs to pick a question and do the presentation in class at the end of the course, and submit the essay after the final.

reviews.author: Brenda ZHANG
reviews.comment_content: Good class to equip people with a common sense of law. It covers a lot of topics such as human rights, sea, air, environment, etc. Not suitable for those who have no interest in law though.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is very nice! Will continue to do UROP with him this semester.
reviews.comment_grading: I wrote a 12-page essay with my partner and got A+. Lecture videos are released 10 days before exams so I didn't attend lectures much.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload at all if you skip the optional essay. Just review the ppt before exams and you are good.

reviews.author: Jason W
reviews.title: Essay saves your grade
reviews.comment_content:
The course give you a lot of freedom, no attendance will be taken for both tutorial and lectures.Workload is also really low, with only one mid term and one final, both consist of MC questions only which make it a really low workload course. Your grade will be based 100% on your exam, however, you can write a voluntary essays and consist 50% of your grade, so exam will only consist of 50%.
For each units, professors will prepare a power point with main-points. Before exam, lectures videos will be provided. A special thing is for every material(including power point or exam etc.) It will provide Chinese translation.
However, for students like me, I find the lectures a bit boring as those cases and law is not so close to our daily life.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is pretty humorous and can also answers most questions that the students has raise up. For teaching assistance, their English may not be that good, so when I attend the English tutorial session, it is not hard to notice the TA is having a hard time when presenting. However, their power point is pretty details and can help review the points mentioned and learnt during lectures.
reviews.comment_grading: From the stat I get, to get into B range, you need about 60% in your exams. Which is not too hard as the exam don't require you to remember many things but just the main points and reason behind. If you want a better grade, you should try to do the essay as the professor is pretty lenient in essays, the lowest he gave in our class is B, so I guess you can do pretty well in the essay part.
reviews.comment_workload: As I mentioned, the workload is really light as the work you have to do is only prepare for the two exams with MC questions only. However, if you decide to do the essay, get prepared for a heavier workload, but the professor will provide help whenever you ask so it should be bearable.

reviews.author: Jellobeano
reviews.title: Interesting lesson but poor grades
reviews.comment_content: Mid terms and finals are all multiple choices.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lessons were all recorded, attendance is not required. Many things mentioned during the class are out of syllabus,  just remember to study the powerpoint and be really familiar with the cases.
reviews.comment_grading: The grades are fixed, you can roughly predict your grades by counting the number of correctly answered  multiple choice questions.
reviews.comment_workload: You can choose whether to do a paper or not. According to Berry, students get better grades when they apply to do a paper.There is no assignments yet you need to study really hard to get good grades.

reviews.author: queenb
reviews.title: Nice Course
reviews.comment_content:
It's content focus on different aspects of international law. It got a quite sensible logic flow. From the history of International laws tp environmental aspects, military aspects, world peaces etc.

The major revision point is to revise how the examples' related to the law principle. The details of each example are not required to recite. Clearly understanding is needed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The course is fun if you are interested in law. The professor use many examples to explain the principle or law.
If you are a bit confused in the course content, it is pretty common for students to raise questions.
And the tutorials are basically act as weekly review of lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: Many international students taking this course, they usually will finish a paper with their familiar knowledge, therefore they potentially get a higher grade. People doing paper nearly guarantee a higher grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
0% workload.
No attendance record is taken, including both tutorials and lectures.
No homework at all.
Before mid-term and finals, the tutors will send all the videos link, so you and learn it all at home.

reviews.author: FatFart
reviews.title: Generally speaking, it is a very good course for extra learning, but don't expect to have a very good grade
reviews.comment_content: It is quite inreresting if you are interested in law. It touched different apsects in law around the world and listed many cases and examples. You may need to know the development on a specific law as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is one of the best pof. I have ever met.  His teaching is very clear and concise, and very interesting as well, since he will not simply read out the power-point, which a lot pof. do.
reviews.comment_grading: Maybe because there are too many students who are enthusiastic to the course, the grade is not very good.
reviews.comment_workload: All most zero workload. No homework, both exam only cover its power-point content.  Also, final exam will not ask about the content before mid-term.

reviews.author: Gloria Chow
reviews.title: good grade if you can study hard on your own
reviews.comment_content:
mainly concerns international affairs and of course, international law. Can learn a lot about the history of different countries, and get some basic concepts in I law. good to boarden your horizon.

1 mid term, 1 final, optional paper with 1 partner.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Sautman teaches quite well. Class is interesting. But TAs can't help you much, probably because they don't know much about international law too.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. I got an A at last but I would say I still havent study very thoroughly before I went to exams.
reviews.comment_workload: Need to take a lot of time to study on your own. Really require hard work to get good grade.

reviews.author: Gillian
reviews.comment_content: It is quite inreresting if you are interested in law. It touched different apsects in law around the world and listed many cases and examples. You may need to know the development on a specific law as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Barry is a very highly-qualified professor and he made jokes in class as well. You don't need to attend class since there were lecture video posted after the class. You may watch those videos few days before the exam and then you can get a decent grade.
reviews.comment_grading: It's not bad. I got B+ and one score to get an A-. You need to read and memorize all the materials in class and examples to answer all the eam questions.
reviews.comment_workload: there was no assignment and only had optional presentation for replacing your final exam grade.

reviews.author: Guillaume
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting content: covers legal aspects of sea, land, sky, weapon regulations, and many other fields in a very short but informative class. For those who are interested in international affairs, this is probably the best class that UST has to offer. Those interested in MUN can also consider taking this class as this class provides a lot of background knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Barry Sautman is one of the better professors in the SS deparment. This class took place in a lecture theater, but his voice is so audible that no form of auditory aid is needed. Sautman carries the class at an appropriate pace, and is always eager to answer students' questions. He is a lawyer who has advanced knowledge in the legal career, which is very rare in this university.
reviews.comment_grading: This class has a considerably large C and D range, and since assessment materials for this class is much fewer than that of other classes, it is relatively easy for a student to receive lower than A grades. If you become one of the lucky people to do a paper and puts in regular effort for this class, then it's almost guaranteed that you will have no less than a B. There are two exams, each counting roughly 50% of your final grade, and is entirely multiple-choice. Many of the questions come from lecture materials that is not explicitly mentioned in the powerpoints, so it is better to attend the classes regularly.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost no workload during the semester. Unless you chose to do a paper with a partner, there is virtually no assignment for this class.

reviews.author: Ver
reviews.comment_content:
MIDTERM TOPICS:
- History of International Law
- Treaties & Customs
- States & Sovereignty
- Human Rights
FINAL TOPICS
- Sea, Air & Space Laws
- Laws on the Environment
- Use of Force
- Peaceful Settlement
- Student presentation topics

Generally, really interesting but dense topics.
The course tests you on understanding of concepts, but memorization is needed as well, especially of key case studies and their significance in international law.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Sautman's teaching is very clear, and he is a very engaging lecturer. He encourages students to ask questions during and after the lectures, and he answers every question very well. He definitely has a lot of knowledge on and experience in the field.
The TAs' optional tutorials were sometimes helpful in summarizing. The practice questions could be confusing at times, though. One time the TA gave us an answer we debated, only to have the answer changed once it was uploaded on Canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 48 MC questions
Final: 52 MC questions
9 people/pairs who volunteer and make the lucky draw can write a paper and present on a topic of their choice, accounting for 50% of their final grade. People writing the paper have plenty of resources during the course to help them write a good-quality paper, and they work hard, so their paper/presentation grades tend to boost their overall mark.
Grading was fair; boundaries seem pretty narrow. As long as you put in a fair amount of effort to go to lectures and do some reading, you should be able to earn a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Unless you need to write the paper and make the presentation, there isn't any mandatory work for the course. You don't even have to attend lectures if you don't want to; videos and lecture notes are uploaded before each exam. (Of course, it's recommended to attend the lecture.) The professor hands out readings on current/related events, and there are textbooks named in the syllabus, but these are optional readings. I'd recommend reading at least some of the articles or textbook chapters, though; they really help out during studying.

reviews.author: fierce_bad_girl
reviews.comment_content: Probably the best course in UST for people interested in International Relations theory or who have some sort of background in law. Topics covered include treaties and customs, states and international organisations, human rights, sea, air and space law, environmental law and the use of force.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Brilliant professor - he's a mildly funny Canadian and hence enjoys making occasional (hilarious) jabs at US politics. Cites engaging examples from current world news, integrates case studies with theory and manages to make a topics that could've been boring as heck interesting. He tends to be quite scatty and unstructured though in that his powerpoints are just random points (with bilingual translations, I'll give him that).
His TAs aren't the best though - their accents make the (optional) tutorials quite slow and difficult to understand, although their powerpoints are usually fantastically structured.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair. 9 pairs of students (chosen by lottery) get to write a paper on a topic of your choice related to IL, in which case grading will be 50% paper 25% midterm 25% final. On average this pushes your grade up by a whole letter. There are 48 MC questions on the midterm and 52 on the final, 13 of which are based on the student presentations.
reviews.comment_workload: Unless you choose to write the paper (which will be 12-15 pages plus a 25 minute presentation) there is pretty much no workload. All you have to do is keep (somewhat) up to date with the textbook chapters. Apart from the 2 usual lectures a week there's also a one hour optional tutorial which really helps you summarize the substantial info you've been presented with during the lectures.

reviews.author: polarbear
reviews.title: If you like law or need SOSC Credit, it's a must
reviews.comment_content: It covers topics about International Law. Includes the history and sources of IL, states and international organizations; human rights; sea, air and space law; environmental law; the use of force; and the peaceful settlement of disputes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Barry is enthusiastic and passionate about this course. He gives lots of examples in his lecture. A couple of these come out on the finals (but not covered on the lecture notes). His lectures feel like barry's storytime (kinda mundane, but not as much).
reviews.comment_grading:
You can choose from two options for your grading: 100% Final || ( 50% Final && 50% Paper) Only a limited amount of people can write papers, and it is chosen by lucky draw. If you get lucky, it will be easier for you to get better grades than other people.

Mean was 46.5 out of 80, with an SD of 9.5. The highest score was 66 for Fall 20/21. Barry does give a generous curve  A: 23.8% B: 35.4% C:  29.3% D: 6.6% F: 4.9% But it is easy to fall into the C range, so be aware of that.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is generally 0. There is no attendance, quiz, or HW (if you are not writing a paper). But you might want to attend those classes where students give their presentations as those will also be on the final exam. If you study for a solid week for the final, that would be enough for you to get a good grade.

reviews.author: mushroom
reviews.comment_content: Contents are interesting. Some are related to life, making it not difficult to memorize.
reviews.comment_teaching: Barry is very humorous, while his tone makes us sleepy. I prefer to watch lecture videos after class lol. Lots of information are not given in the slides, so make sure to take notes. His lecture videos require hours to go through (for me, more than 2 hours).
reviews.comment_grading:
Can choose to do an essay or not
Do essay:
50% essay, presentation
50% midterm+final
No essay:
50% midterm
50% final

Fall 19-20 doesn't have the presentation part since class arrangement, so the final exam only had 39 questions.
I did not sign up for the essay and got 1.3 sd above in midterm and 1.5 sd above in final. Got an A. Maybe people writing essays get a better grade as Barry said, but I still appreciate the grade for the workload.
reviews.comment_workload: Start studying a week before the exam is enough. The midterm exam comes soon after the add-drop period so study earlier.

reviews.author: whrchan
reviews.comment_content: Basic International Law topics such as history of IL,treaties,law of sea, air, space etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very clear and ppt provided, maybe boring sometimes, but he is very nice and you may ask him questions.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good grade, you may get a better grade if you choose to do a voluntary presentation. But the grade is already good enough if you don't do it. Marks slightly higher than the mean could already get an A-.
reviews.comment_workload: Best among all courses. No attendance for lectures, no homework, all MCs for exams. You just need to memorize some ppt and some cases which didn't take much time

reviews.author: Timmy
reviews.title: Good Grade, Good Teacher and Interesting Content
reviews.comment_content: The content includes basic international law concept, and different areas of international law, like Sea, Air & Space Law, Human Right, the Use of Force etc. There are a number of cases for each topic since the note comes in both Chinese and English, it should be easy to understand. Cases are interesting and some cases really surprise you (at least it surprised me).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Barry is very nice, and he understands some topics are quite boring so he does provide lecture videos, so if you don't understand just go back and watch the video or just ask him directly.

Since he is from the US, his English is very good and easy to understand, you can Google search for him, he really has a page on Wikipedia.

Some lectures are boring, but it's really not the professor's problem, it's the topics and it's law how exciting can it be.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 Exams (MC) (each question in both English and Chinese)
1 Research Paper (optional)

According to the Prof people who do the research paper tend to have a better grade, I didn't do the research paper but I still got an A for this course, it's really just about memoizing, but to me, the course content is interesting so it's easier for me.

Exams are just MC about 84 questions will be based on lectures and 16 on student presentations, so if you pay attention it won't be hard.
reviews.comment_workload: The tutorial is optional, no attendance is required, there are lecture videos, so if you don't do the research paper, there's is nothing to do at all, just a few readings and attend the class and that's it.

reviews.author: Claire~
reviews.title: Convenient course!
reviews.comment_content: The course includes basic international law concepts along with classic cases in history. The contents are still valuable today as the law develops to suit today's situation and needs.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Canadian instructor, no accent, obviously.
He tried his best to tell us more stories but his voice makes me want to sleep.
Good thing is that this course has lecture videos.
reviews.comment_grading:
Amazingly great.
I was below mean in the midterm and finally got an A-
midterm+final = 100 MCs = 100 points
this is the only grading scheme if you dont want to write papers. No attend, no parti. Easy and convenient.
reviews.comment_workload: I can't say the workload is light because it requires a lot of memorizing. But that' all you need to do. Just remember everything then you can get the MCs right. There are only 2 tests. No quizzes, no assignments, no nothing. You don't need to attend the letures, just sit in the dorm and watch all the vedios and wirte down important notes. Then remember the cases and the principles they reflects. That's all he is gonna test you in the exams. No presen, no group work, just enjoy.

reviews.author: mzimmer
reviews.comment_content: History and basic info about lnternational law. Nice if you don’t know much about law and international organisations (especially UN). Attending tutorials is quite useful, but TAs aren’t experts so don’t expect them answering difficult questions. Anyway - tutorial slides are a lot more useful, as those provided by prof. Barry are quite chaotic. Reading a book may be helpful but mesmerising the slides is enough for a good grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: After 20 minutes gets a bit boring (but come on - it’s law). He really likes it when students ask a lot of questions, so please do. Also professor quite dislikes the US and is way much “nice” when it comes to China, which may be seen as a bit unfair (he’s Canadian btw).
reviews.comment_grading:
Some exam questions are a bit tricky, so you should read all the questions carefully. Generally - mesmerise all the slides and try to write a research paper, as it may affect your grade (positively of course). If you’re even a bit above the mean - expect a B.

Generally good grading, but those who don’t study at all - getting C or D is highly possible.
reviews.comment_workload: For those who don’t have a research paper to write - not much at all. You don’t even have to come to the lectures, nor tutorials.

reviews.author: yymic
reviews.comment_content:
International law introduction and examples mainly.
Topics: History, Treaties, States, Human Rights, Law of Sea, Air and Outerspace, Environmental Law, Use of Force and Peaceful Settlement.

A bit complicated and you really have to study thoroughly.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is an interesting professor. You can know some fun facts about international laws and stuff, and he gladly answers any questions.
His voice is low and the pace is simply slow. Many find that sleepy, and the slides are just boring to say it only has words and words.
Hate to say that watching the lecture videos is a better choice than attending his lectures. It is so long and in a sleepy afternoon. But if you have true interest and questions, you will find the course interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
I must say that only if you have a good understanding of this course, you will get a high score. I find the concepts quite confusing and need to look up wiki for every topic. The 5 practice questions for final is basically not a good example. And yup, I didn't get a good grade. But I know people do get good scores.

Presentations seem to lead you to better gradings, but my friend doesn't seem to have a significant uplift in her marks, so.
reviews.comment_workload: If you skip those extra reading materials, you don't have any workload.

reviews.author: 吖享
reviews.comment_content: It simply introduces us the fundamental concepts of international law which are the same as the one people are taught in Harvard Law School. Much as there were lots of cases introduced during the lessons, they were simple and do not really need deep understanding or memorizing strictly.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Barry is one fantastic lecturer, not only he can explain everything in detail which makes everyone understands the conceptions of laws, but also he accepts all kinds of questions during and after his classes to make sure everyone can thoroughly learn the ppt.
reviews.comment_grading: It is without doubt that the grading is generous. 50% mid-term and 50% final, and only 100 mc in total, once you got 70% right, you got yourself an A grade. The questions were not hard and quite straight-forward, mainly related to concepts but not details of cases.
reviews.comment_workload:
No particular workload I would say
No webwork
Optional essay and presentations
ONLY mid-term and final which consists of 100 mc in total

reviews.author: ArthurMorgan
reviews.comment_content: So this is basically a history course more than a law course. You will learn the history of I.L. and how I.L. is being applied in different contexts. FYI, there will be tons of cases and details of treaties to memorize, but if you are good at memorizing things, then this course should not be a problem for you!
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Barry Sautman is a very kind professor and so enthusiastic about teaching. His tone in teaching is pretty acceptable and not boring. Even though some of the content of the lessons is boring, I can see he was trying his best to make things clear and interesting! Moreover, he loves students raising questions or bring up controversial topics.
reviews.comment_grading: If you are a hardworking student and have the ability to memorize all treaties and cases, then you might able to score a B. But if you want more than a B, then you will have to do more than just memorizing but also "understanding". Because the questions in the test are usually situations and usually require the understanding of a certain topic more than the exact wording of the topic. All in all, the questions in the test/exam is rather easy.
reviews.comment_workload: ZERO workloads, no assignment, 1 midterm, 1 final exam. There is an optional paper writing though, you can either do it alone or team up with 1 person to complete the paper.
